name: Argyll and Bute Council
systems: Sentiment Metrics social media sentiment analysis
notes: It appears the social media sentiment analysis is a part of a system (ContactCentre 59R ACD) which groups together different streams individual may use to contact an organisation, including social media. The sentiment analysis portion is provided by Sentiment Metrics, who are now called Sentiment. - http://www.monitoring-social-media.com/sentiment-metrics-undergoes-rebrand-and-launches-sentiment
extract: "We use the Sentiment Metrics social media service which uses algorithms to determine user sentiment about the council based on customer social media postings. ... Both Sentiment metrics and the voice auto service form part of a wider customer engagement solution contract with Softcat PLC who subcontracted Oracle and Netcall for the relevant elements " [More details within the FOI response]

name: Birmingham City Council
notes: A popular business intelligence package, sold by SAP. Has a wide array of possible functions, including analytical capacities. Marketing copy extract: "Enable all business users to understand trends and root causes with easy-to-use BI tools for ad hoc queries, reporting, and analysis in a Web environment. ... Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html

name: Birmingham City Council
notes: A popular, versatile "visual analytics" platform. - https://www.tableau.com/

name: Blaby District Council
notes: This popular piece of "geodemographic segmentation" software is used to gain insights into different populations of people, down to the level of neighbourhood (postcode) and household. See page 83 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for a closer look at Mosaic: https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: Bournemouth Borough Council use AccsMap alongside a number of other applications to attempt to understand traffic flows. From AccsMap's marketing copy: "AccsMap is a map-based road casualty analysis system developed  specifically for the UK. It is a comprehensive input, reporting,  analysis and validation system for road accidents, enabling data to be  viewed and interrogated on a map background." - http://www.buchanancomputing.net/accsmap.html
extract: "AccsMap is used to organise and analyse road casualty data."

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: Arcady is used to model roundabouts. More information: https://trlsoftware.com/products/junction-signal-design/junctions/arcady/

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: Among other things relating to website UX, SiteImprove provides analytics tools to measure how users interact with a website.

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: An urban traffic management and control system which uses "data analysis and auto-adaptive management of traffic light networks". - https://www.indracompany.com/en/control-systems
extract: "We use Urban Traffic Management and Control (UTMC) systems such as Scoot, Mova and Stratos to assess traffic flows and automatically adjust traffic signals to optimise traffic flow and help reduce congestion."

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A fairly old urban traffic control system, in use since at least the 90s, which utilises sensors to optimise traffic flows with traffic signals. - http://www.ukroads.org/webfiles/tal04-95.pdf

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A customer experience system, now called Orlo. Orlo carries out a degree of sentiment analysis, although it is unclear if Bournemouth Borough Council use this aspect of the system[1]. The system also has some social media monitoring capabilities[2]. - [1] https://orlo.tech/our-ecosystem/social-customer-care/  [2] https://orlo.tech/our-ecosystem/media-monitoring/

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A Siemens produced system with a wide array of capabilities, including the processing of real-time sensor information. Processing is carried out on Siemens' servers. - https://www.siemens.co.uk/traffic/en/index/productssolutionsservices/systems/traffic-management-system-stratos.htm

name: Bournemouth Borough Council
notes: A popular, versatile "visual analytics" platform. - https://www.tableau.com/
extract: "The Insight, Policy and Performance Team have just started to use Tableau for data visualisation. Our tableau dashboards can be seen here: https://public.tableau.com/profile/bcpinsight#!/ "

name: City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council
notes: A system used for data linkage, with the aim of analytics being performed upon the linked data data. Bradford City Council use the system for schools allocation based on a number of factors. CapitaONE is produced by the public sector outsourcing giant, Capita. Capita market the system as allowing local authorities to see the "full picture" of their citizens and facilitating effective interventions[1]. See page 99 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more on Capita[2].  [1] https://www.capita-one.co.uk/about-us  [2] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: "CapitaONE - schools allocation based on parents selection and other criteria such as distance etc"

name: City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council
notes: The LCS is a system, provided by LiquidLogic, developed to support "all aspects of social work with children", including case management and record keeping. It attempts to unify record keeping and can assist the social worker user in making connections within a case. From LiquidLogic's marketing copy: "Not simply an electronic social care record, the system can assist practitioners’ professional judgement by helping to make connections within a case, which may not otherwise be so apparent. ... the system reacts dynamically to information it is given."[1] The Early Help Module "is a complete solution designed to act as a general case management tool for children outside of Social Care", also provided by LiquidLogic [2] It is commonly used in conjunction with the LCS, including by Bradford City Council in this example.  [1] https://www.liquidlogic.co.uk/children/liquidlogic-childrens-system-lcs/  [2] https://www.liquidlogic.co.uk/children/early-help-module-ehm/
extract: "LCS (including Early Help) - child assessments and service levels determined by input of assessment info"

name: London Borough of Brent
notes: Risk Based Verification (RBV) systems attempt to predict the risk of a benefit claim and, in response, adapt how that claim is processed. See pages 96-100 of the Data Justice Lab's report, "Data Scores as Governance", for more information on three providers of RBV systems. - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
extract: The Benefit Service uses Risk Based Verification (RBV) software in the processing of new claims (NC) and changes in circumstances (CIC) relating to Housing Benefit and Council Tax Support claims. Claimants make new claims and report changes via online electronic forms, and having provided the required information about their family circumstances, a RBV “score” is generated via referral to a third party web-based RBV product. The RBV software uses a propensity model based on national data relating to the relative likelihood, or “risk”, of the claimant’s claim being susceptible to fraud or error. The NC or CIC is thus risk-scored and differing levels of evidence are required, depending on the risk score, to support the claim; the higher the risk scoring, the greater the evidence requirement before the claim is processed.

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
systems: "delivering projects involving advanced analytics (e.g. prediction and modelling)"
notes: In a strategy paper attached to their Freedom of Information request response, Brighton and Hove City Council their intention to use use predictive analytics, either in the present or future.
extract: From 'Data Insight Strategy Paper', attached to the FOI response: "These are capabilities that allow us to extract insight from data in innovative ways, allowing us to use historical data to predict the future, model alternative scenarios, test out policies virtually. These can be supervised by an analyst or be unsupervised (using machine learning). The potential benefits are significant but it requires specialist tools and expertise to ensure the outputs are meaningful."

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: In a presentation attached to the Freedom of Information request response, B&HCC name ArcGIS under "mapping" and "network analysis" on a slide detailing their "Data Insight Strategy analytics toolkit". Esri, who produce ArcGIS, claim, among other things, that the system can "Analyze patters to make predictions and determine next steps". - https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/products/arcgis-online/capabilities/analyze-data

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: A popular business intelligence package, sold by SAP. Has a wide array of possible functions, including analytical capacities. Marketing copy extract: "Enable all business users to understand trends and root causes with easy-to-use BI tools for ad hoc queries, reporting, and analysis in a Web environment. ... Build impactful BI visualization, dashboards, and analytics applications to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities." - https://www.sap.com/products/bi-platform.html
extract: "Currently, our primary BI platform is Business Objects. We are piloting dashboard tools like Tableau and Power BI. We may also use Excel or infographic tools, depending on requirements."

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: This reference within the Freedom of Information response perhaps refers to an instance of SAP's Business Objects. A comment on the FOI response indicates this predictive analytics system is possibly being used for "Access Point analytics", although it is unclear what this refers to.
extract: B&HCC wrote in the main body of their FOI response: "BHCC is not using any data analytics, predictive analytics or algorithmic automated systems" However, the Word document contained a perhaps mistakenly included comment on this line which reads: "What about SAP Predictive Analytics? What tool is [an employee] going to be using for the Access Point analytics?"

name: Brighton and Hove City Council
notes: A popular, versatile "visual analytics" platform. - https://www.tableau.com/
extract: From the presentation attached to the FOI response: "Using a flexible intuitive tool to explore data and discover new insights [Tableau, Lumira, Power BI, Excel]"

name: Bristol City Council
notes: Bristol City Council's Freedom of Information response suggests that Qlik Sense is a data analytics platform being used as part of Bristol City Council's Think Family system. In their report, "Data Scores as Governance", the Data Justice Lab include a case study on the use of Qlik Sense by Avon & Somerset Police (the police force responsible for Bristol), where "it serves as both a performance assessment tool and a predictive policing tool"[1]. This use of Qlik Sense may overlap with the use of Qlik Sense by Avon & Somerset Police. See page 75 of the Data Justice Lab's report for more on the use of Qlik Sense by Avon & Somerset Police, and see page 28 for more on Think Family[1]. Qlik boast that, thanks to "the Associative engine at its core, and new augmented intelligence capabilities ... Qlik Sense helps ... discover insights" and can "[t]ake advantage of machine suggestions and automation powered by the Qlik cognitive engine"[2]. - [1] https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf  [2] https://www.qlik.com/us/products/qlik-sense
extract: "The system [Think Family] is running on a combination of software.  It uses SSIS for ETL, SSRS for front line staff accessing the system, SPSS for predictive modelling and Qlik Sense for MI and analytical functions."

name: Bristol City Council
notes: Think Family was established as Bristol City Council's approach to the Troubled Families programme, with the aim "to encourage services to deal with families as a whole, rather than responding to each problem or person, separately". Bristol CC developed a Think Family Database that consolidated information from 35 different social issue datasets, about 54,000 families in the local authority area, to understand the strategic and operational needs of the city. The database is up and running and is now able to provide information to predict future need as well as simply responding to presenting issues. Think Family is covered as part of the Data Justice Lab's case study on the Bristol Integrated Analytical Hub within their report, "Data Scores as Governance" (p.28). - https://datajustice.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/data-scores-as-governance-project-report2.pdf
